author: Betsy Hammond | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: How much does former Oregon schools chief Rob Saxton get from PERS? Answer is in
text:
When Oregon's first appointed state schools chief decided to "retire" from that high-profile job at age 55 to take another government job, The Oregonian/OregonLive speculated that he would receive at least $100,000, and as much as $140,000, in yearly public employee retirement benefits.
That pension would be on top of the $197,000 that Rob Saxton now collects -- $160,000 in salary plus $37,000 toward a tax-deferred annuity -- as head of the Northwest Regional Education Service District .
Now the official figure has been made public. Saxton will be paid $120,000 a year for the rest of his life in pension benefits for his 31 years working in public education, ending with his three years in the $200,000-a-year state schools chief job.
Officials at the Public Employee Retirement System released the pension figure at the request of The Oregonian/OregonLive.
